      On Mon, Apr 13, 2009 at 11:44 AM, Jo=
hn S <phenom_investigator@...> wrote:





        The problem we run=
 into is what actually constitutes evidence of spirit communication? This i=
s the heart of the matter. As I said in the other thread, one cannot simply=
 assume that unexplained information defacto proves spirit communication or=
 even external sources. 

        The reason is simple. It is quite possibl=
e for internal and/or external influences to be exerted in an experiment. L=
et us say you are doing an experiment and you are the only participant. We'=
ll set aside the obvious challenge of reporting credibility for the moment.=
 How do you truly know it's not you and even worse, how do you know who in =
fact the external communicator is? Simply knowing facts is not sufficient. =
Especially in cases where PK may be in play (such as the Ouija example) a r=
emote PK agent could be influencing the planchette. Before ruling this out,=
 consider that the very notion that anyone is moving anything is problemati=
c for many people. And spirit communication pushes the edge of the belief e=
nvelope for others. In the end, all of this is some form of anomalous pheno=
mena. You could know things of which you are unaware. Consider that you mig=
ht be clairvoyant and not even realize it. If you were to externalize this =
through a latent PK mechanism, bingo, you are the agent and the source of i=
nformation. Yet to all appearances the information came from elsewhere and =
you therefore presume it must be external to yourself, which in this exampl=
e would not be true..



        I was taking advantage of the physical nat=
ure of the experiment I proposed. Unfortunately this is what is required if=
 one wishes to remove reliance on belief systems alone. This is what many i=
n the field are looking for. From my own work with mediums and other sensit=
ives, I have learned the perils and the potential pitfalls with our own per=
ceptual systems, memories and recall. All of this works against us in even =
the most trivial experimental set up, which is unfortunate but true. This i=
s yet one more reason to exercise caution with solely anecdotal experimenta=
l outcomes. You will find that independent historical validation is actualy=
 pretty tricky, as I have said before, because it often is not simply factu=
al in nature. It tends to be more about emotions and feelings and that's wh=
ere specifically identifying an individual gets dicey.



        I wish yo=
u all the best in your efforts, whatever path you may chose.



          J=
S
